Care Home & Care Agency Requests for Blister Packs ............................................... 9
Introduction

The Royal Pharmaceutical Society 2013 guidance on the better use of medication compliance aids (MCAs) suggests the use of original packs of medication with appropriate support is the preferred option of supply in the absence of a specific need requiring a blister pack.

Blister packing is where solid dosage medications are decanted into medication aids which are compartmentalised according to days of the week, times of the day etc. (i.e. into a multi-compartment compliance aid).

In support of independence and re-ablement, patients who can safely self- administer their medicines should be encouraged to do so and where they are unable to do so, there must be appropriate training for carers so that they are able to administer medicines from original packaging.
Policy, training and support for carers are provided locally by Essex County Council and Southend Borough Council; please see section 8.

Every patient identified as having medicines adherence issues is to have a robust individual assessment undertaken to identify the best intervention based on their needs and the evidence currently available. This policy outlines how this assessment is undertaken.

This policy is designed to be used by all staff who are involved in the prescribing, administration, supply or monitoring of medication. It is intended to assist pharmacy staff, prescribers and nursing and rehabilitation staff in enabling & supporting people to manage their medicines.
The term “medicines support” is defined as any support that enables a person to manage their medicines & ensure they get the most out of their medication.
All decisions relating to medication should be discussed and agreed with patients and/or carer where possible.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Help ward and pharmacy staff to identify patients who are having difficulty taking their medicines and access which (if any) medication aids would be suitable to aid independent compliance.

Support consideration of using a multi-compartment compliance aid only when an assessment has been completed by a member of pharmacy staff and a specific need has been identified to support medicines adherence.
Consider the patients' needs and preferences, and if needed, involve family members or carers (see- Appendix 1 Medication assessment tool).
Definitions

table_items.text: May be formal (e.g. domiciliary care workers) or informal (e.g. relatives) and are to be considered for the scope of this document any person who prompts, assists or administers medication to patients.
The Electronic Prescribing and Administration System used by the Trust on main wards instead of traditional paper drug charts. Also referred to as electronic prescribing.

Medication Administration Record. This is a part of a patient's permanent record on their medical chart. The health care professional signs off on the record at the time that the drug or device is administered. This is often used in care homes instead of a traditional drug chart used in hospitals.
Any device which can be supplied to a patient to assist them with taking their medicines e.g. blister packs, non-childproof containers etc.
Multi- compartment compliance aid Or Multi- compartment Dispensing Systems (MDS) –also referred to as a ‘Blister Pack'
Where solid dosage medications are decanted into medication aids which are compartmentalised according to days of the week, times of the day etc.
For the purposes of this document, all registered, authorised, administering practitioners
A container which is presented to the patient in its original form i.e. not tampered with and with full contents and information leaflets.

A service which allows Trust pharmacy staff to send an electronic message to a patient's nominated community pharmacy at discharge. This is to provide recommendations or information as part of the community pharmacy Discharge Medicines Service.

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
MSE Patient Safety & Quality Group
Receiving exception reports and taking action in response to issues raised from Medicines Assurance Group and/or department of pharmacy.
MSE Medicines Assurance Group
Ensuring the effective implementation, use and timely review of this policy;
Ensuring that monitoring arrangements are appropriately performed by the site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Groups (MOSG);
Where necessary, escalating concerns to the Chief Nurse or site Director of Nursing or Medical Director as appropriate;
Exception reporting to the MSE Patient Safety & Quality Group on developments, concerns and progress concerning medication compliance aid use.
Site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Group (MOSG)
Monitoring this policy through incident reports;
Escalating issues to site divisional governance groups and MAG as appropriate.
Chief Executive

As the Trust's Accountable Officer has overall responsibility for ensuring the Trust has robust, complete and up to date documents in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
Chief Nursing Officer
Ensuring that there is policy compliance and liaising with the site Pharmacy, Head of Department & site Pharmacy Operational Lead that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring any escalated medication compliance aid issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Site Directors of Nursing / Deputy Directors of Nursing
Ensuring that there is policy compliance on site by all professions they oversee and that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring any escalated medication compliance aid issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately;
Chief Pharmacist
Setting the overall framework and policy standards for medication compliance aid across the organisation, in line with regulatory and best practice guidance;
Ensuring a monitoring process exists and functions for policy standard.
The Chief Pharmacist delegates this responsibility to the site pharmacy Heads of Department and site Pharmacy Operational Leads for delivery.
Pharmacy Directorate Governance Group and Pharmacy Board
Monitoring this policy through incident reports or any complaints or comments received from patients or staff;
Taking action with respect to pharmacy service delivery.
Site Pharmacy Operational Lead
Ensuring that there is policy compliance by site pharmacy services and assuring pharmacy governance meeting/ pharmacy board that the service is operating effectively.
Registered Pharmacy Staff
Signposting this policy to ward staff;
Supporting and carrying out medication assessments in conjunction with nursing staff and patients, where appropriate;
Optimising medication regimens with view to simplifying regimens, where possible;
Monitoring a patients continuing ability to use their medicines and reviewing or suggesting alternatives when appropriate;
Supplying appropriate medication aids and instructing patients in their correct use, based on assessment outcome.
Pharmacy support staff (i.e. dispensary staff, procurement staff)
Sign posting this policy to ward staff;
Maintaining stock of compliance aids in the dispensary;
Dispensing appropriate compliance aid on receipt of a valid medication assessment and order from a registered pharmacist or registered pharmacy technician.
Prescribers
Prescribing appropriately with patient needs taken into account, using the medication assessment (appendix 1), where appropriate;
Referring patients to pharmacy staff, where necessary, if a patient is struggling with taking their medication.
Registered Nursing staff
Carrying out medication assessments in conjunction with pharmacy staff where appropriate. These assessments are distinct from the self-administration medication assessments;
Consulting with pharmacy staff to determine the best option for a particular patient before agreeing with the patient;
Assisting patients with the administration of their medication, which should include educating them or reinforcing messages about how to administer their medicines.
Rehabilitation and Social care staff
Assisting the multi-disciplinary team in decision making, in line with this policy.
Patient Assessment for intervention with a medication compliance
aid
Patient assessment incorporates a clinical medication review, any reasons for non- adherence, medicines suitability, a consideration of all possible options to support the patient and follow up.

The assessment is best carried out by the multidisciplinary team, which may include: a doctor, pharmacist, pharmacy technician, staff nurse, social worker and a representative from occupational therapy / rehabilitation as appropriate.
All assessments must consider the current Equality Act and Mental Capacity Act, and be in line with the relevant Trust policies concerning these Acts.
The only valid assessment for deciding which, if any, compliance aids are recommended is appendix 1 of this policy and not any other organisation or locally devised assessment.
Not all medication is suitable for blister packing and this must be considered as part of the assessment. Please see section 9.

If the assessment identifies that, as part of the patient's care package, additional aid(s) for medicines compliance is required, appendix 1 guides as to what may be the most appropriate intervention; this may or may not include the use of blister packs.

To provide patients with the appropriate medicines compliance aids, the Medication Assessment Tool (Appendix 1) must be completed, countersigned by a pharmacist and submitted to the designated ward pharmacy team member for processing.
The outcome of the assessment should be recorded on the discharge letter by pharmacy and a message sent to the patient's community pharmacy (with their consent) as part of the PharmOutcomes service.
Medication Review
Compliance aid assessment should be used as an opportunity to optimise medicines usage for the patient.

Registered pharmacists and occasionally registered pharmacy technicians, within their competence, can optimise medication regimens with view to simplifying regimens, where possible. This will be discussed and agreed with the medical team caring for the patient.
Optimisation of the medication regimen should take place regardless of whether blister packs are determined as the best option or not.
Patients admitted with medication compliance aids
Patients may be admitted into hospital with a blister pack or other medication compliance aid in place.
Trust staff should not administer from these except where approved by pharmacy – refer to the Administration of Medicines Policy.
Some patients will be identified by primary care services as essential for blister packs. Pharmacy staff will document this information on the medicines reconciliation undertaken.
Always re-assess the patient using the medication compliance aid assessment tool (appendix 1) because their situation may have changed.

Patients who use medication aids for their own convenience, if they wish to continue to do so on discharge, they must make their own arrangements to continue this practice. This should be done following discussion with a ward pharmacist or technician to address any issues with medication changes during their inpatient stay.

In some cases, pharmacy staff should consider whether patients on blister packs can be offered alternative medication aids if blister packs are no longer considered necessary, in line with the assessment (appendix 1).
Care Home & Care Agency Requests for Blister Packs
There is no legal requirement or any legal case to be made that carers must administer medication from blisters or not at all.
The statement that all drugs must be in blister packs is false and cannot be used as an argument to demand such dispensing.
Carers who administer medication must be trained to administer all medication safely and this includes medicines from original dispensed containers.

Essex County Council and Southend Borough Council both have policies that carers should be trained to prompt, assist or administer medication. These polices do not require blister packaging, only that staff have been trained to carry out these tasks.
Carers can assist/prompt patients supplied with their medication in blister packs

There is no barrier to care homes or agencies using tablet cutters or crushers to assist patients with their medicines and any statement to the contrary is false. Cutting and crushing should however be confirmed as suitable by a pharmacist where not already known. Pharmacists document this clearly on the discharge letter, which is standard practice.
Advice can be sought from the hospital pharmacy following discharge if carers require assistance.
If there is resistance to administration without blister pack supply a copy of Appendix 2: Letter to carers should be made when supplying boxed medication.
Medication which may NOT be suitable for blister packing

Professional guidance produced by NHS specialist pharmacy service (UK Medicines information services) is available to assist pharmacy staff in determining appropriate medication for blister-packing, available at the following destination:
https://www.sps.nhs.uk/articles/usage-of-medicines-in-compliance-aids/
https://www.sps.nhs.uk/category/pharmaceutical-stability-usage/medicines-in- compliance-aid-stability/

However, a professional judgement should always be made, by the registered pharmacist or registered pharmacy technician, where necessary, to determine whether placing any of these medicines in a blister pack is appropriate for a given patient.
Blister packs are not usually suitable for patients:
not orientated in time and place;
who do not have appropriate manual dexterity to open the blister ‘bubbles';
with frequent medication changes. e.g. known adjustments to dosing.
Medication not suitable for blister packing include (but is not exhaustive of):
Medicines sensitive to light, moisture (e.g. dispersible aspirin, orodispersible tablets, dabigatran capsules) and temperature;
Liquid medicines;
Cytotoxic medicines;
Non oral medicines (inhalers, eye drops, nose drops/sprays, creams, ointments, patches, suppositories, pessaries);
Medicines with special handling requirements;
‘When required' medicines;
Variable dose medicines (e.g. warfarin tablets).
Supply of Blister Packs

Blister-packing of medication is a professional exercise incorporating appropriate patient assessment as above as well as pharmaceutical expertise to determine appropriate medication suitable for addition to blister packs (see section 9).
Blister packs, or other suitable compliance interventions, will only be supplied as indicated by the Medication Assessment Tool (Appendix 1).

Where medication aids are assessed & identified, this will be documented clearly, with reasons, in the patient's medical records. This must include the drug chart (for WellSky ePMA (ePrescribing) as a note, as appropriate) and on the TTA discharge

letter itself. Pharmacy staff will usually undertake this task. Other staff should not do this without informing the ward pharmacy team. Such documentation alone is NOT a valid request for blister packs and will not be accepted.
It is not usually acceptable for blister packs to be requested at the time of discharge because preparing a blister pack is time consuming and will delay discharge.

Always make a referral to the ward pharmacist/ near-patient pharmacy technician at ideally 48 hours before discharge, where possible, to enable the appropriate planning. Late referrals will delay dispensing.
If there are special circumstances which mean that blister packs are required with less than 48 hours' notice, these should be discussed with the ward pharmacy team.
Alternative Compliance Aids
Numerous compliance aid options exist which are available to assist patients with their medication. These include:
Medication Administration Record (MAR) sheets – commonly used in care homes;
Inhaler devices (an aid to either help push down the canister in a multi-dose aerosol inhaler (e.g. salbutamol), or twist a turbohaler base);
Tablet cutters;
Tablet crushers.

As well as the devices or items listed in the medication assessment tool (see appendix 1), there may be situations where alternative devices may be utilised or further advice may be required. In these cases, please refer to pharmacy for advice.

When selecting any compliance aid, it is important to consider the benefits to the patient, as well as any possible problems. For example, issuing a tablet cutter may not be safe for a patient who may lack coordination as the sharp blade may cause injury.
Patients must be appropriately counselling by nursing or pharmacy staff in the correct use of any compliance aid provided, such as by demonstration.
Training Requirements
No specific training requirements.

data.text: Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by Medicines Assurance Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local medication documents. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform all prescribers, nursing and pharmacy of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

data.text: Dear Carer
Re: Use of Multi-compartment Dispensing Systems (MDS) (‘Dosette' boxes or Blister Packs.)
Over time there has been a move towards using more MDS packs filled by the pharmacist. These may have some advantages, but they can have some problems too.

Dispensing of medicines into MDS is only funded by the NHS in very limited circumstances, when patients are managing their own medicines without any support from a professional carer, where the medicines are stable outside the manufacturer's packaging and when they have a specific, assessed need that can only be met by use of MDS.
There is no NHS funding for MDS where medicines are prompted or administered by a paid carer, and there are no governance arrangements in place to support this.

Guidance from the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) says that carers must be trained to administer medicines, and that medicines must be supplied with clear and simple instructions on the label that can easily be understood. This is reflected in medication policies that Essex County Council and Southend Borough Council has shared with the social care providers for their areas.
We will be following this guidance and supplying medicines in the most suitable packaging according to relevant legislation and our pharmacist's professional opinion.
Please feel free to discuss this with our pharmacist and share with your employer if necessary.
Thank you
Department of Pharmacy
